ok, the problem is following. it only happens if the user activates the "remember" checkbox during log-in (which is activated by default). in this case the username and a toke gets stored as a cookie on the client but not the (unencrypted) private key. so if the user comes back a new session gets created but without the private key.

i see two solutions:

1. also store the **un**encrypted private key in a cookie on the client if "remember" is checked during log-in. this way we can also restore the private key for the new session. but the private key would be stored in plain text on the client which could rise some security issues.
2. disable the "remember" function if the encryption app is enabled to enforce a log-in if the user comes back. more secure, but also a little bit more inconvenient for the user.

i would like to hear other opinions both from users who reported the issue and from other developers (cc @deepdiver1975 @blizzz @bartv2 @icewind1991 @butonic @bantu @ringmaster @karlitschek ) what do you think?

@jancborchardt what do you think from a ux point of view?

i definitely think that option 2 is the best. 

most browsers today (if not all?) have the ability to store the password in the browser. the function is not exactly the same as checking the "remember" box but almost. this gives the ability for users to save the password for easy login, but also to delete it (from the browser) if you want better security.

itâ´s not such a big effort to have to enter the password every time, and therefore option number 2 is the most secure, and therefore also the best option.
